meanings.def: a strong, hard metal that is made of a mixture of iron and carbon
examples: the iron and steel industry
The frame is made of steel.
Small steel plates were attached to the front and back of the bone.
The bridge is reinforced with huge steel girders.
Lock your bike up so that nobody can steal it.
The best kitchen knives are made from stainless steel.
They had to steel themselves to watch their cherished work being destroyed.
building in steel and aluminium
the advantages of building in steel and glass
Steel used to be important in South Wales.
steel workers
a steel town
The factories and steel mills have now almost disappeared.

meanings.def: a long, thin, straight piece of steel with a rough surface, used for rubbing knives on to make them sharp
weapons that are used for fighting
examples: the clash of steel

meanings.def: having a quality like steel, especially a strong, cold or hard quality
examples: She felt a hand of steel (= a strong, firm hand) on her arm.
You need a cool head and nerves of steel (= great courage).
There was a hint of steel in his voice (= he sounded cold and firm).

idioms.def: having a quality like steel, especially a strong, cold or hard quality
examples: She felt a hand of steel (= a strong, firm hand) on her arm.
You need a cool head and nerves of steel (= great courage).
There was a hint of steel in his voice (= he sounded cold and firm).

meanings.def: to prepare yourself to deal with something unpleasant
examples: steel yourself (for/against something) As she waited, she steeled herself for disappointment.
steel yourself to do something He steeled himself to tell them the truth.
Lock your bike up so that nobody can steal it.
The best kitchen knives are made from stainless steel.
They had to steel themselves to watch their cherished work being destroyed.
